frameDefinitions: An Experiencer, Expressor, or State can be described as having a surprised emotion as evoked by a Stimulus or concerning a Topic.
A Winner has victory over an Loser.
Some phenomenon (the Stimulus) provokes a particular emotion in an Experiencer.
In this frame, a Communicator judges the Addressee and then communicates that appraisal directly to the Addressee.

A Phenomenon (an external or cognitive event or situation) comes into the awareness of an Experiencer, resulting in a perceptually punctual change in the Experiencer's conception of the Phenomenon or entities and facts associated with it.
frameExamples: I was more <t>shocked</t> about the child than she was.
Nightmare on Elm Street <t>scared</t> me silly.
The principal <t>rebuked</t> the student for cheating on the exam.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the general area in which the emotion occurs.  It indicates a range of possible <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

The body part, gesture, or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflects his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Experiencer</fen>, <fen>Expressor</fen>, or <fen>State</fen> can be described as having said emotion.
The individual or individuals who beat the <fen>Loser</fen>.
The individual or individuals that get beat by the <fen>Winner</fen>.
When the <fen>Winner</fen> has victory over the <fen>Loser</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Winner</fen> has victory <fen>Loser</fen>.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> reacts emotionally or psychologically to the <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the event or entity which brings about the emotional or psychological state of the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has an emotion as caused by the <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates a judgment to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The <fen>Addressee</fen> is jduged by the <fen>Communicator</fen> and receives the message of approval or disapproval.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject on which the <fen>Addressee</fen> is being judged.
The <fen>Reason</fen> is why the Communicator forms the type of judgment they form.
The <fen>Medium</fen> identifies the physical or abstract entity in which the judgment is conveyed.
An action or entity under the control of the <fen>Communicator</fen> that expresses the criticism or praise directed towards the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The point in time at which the <fen>Communicator</fen> berates or compliments the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Communicator</fen> admonishes the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is the entity that evokes a cognitive reaction for the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> in the entity who experiences the cognitive impact brought about by the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The news</fex> greatlyalarms all the women of the village.
The teacher scolded the children <fex>about their meessy cookie eating</fex>.
The principal rebuked the student <fex>for cheating on the exam</fex>.
Though she had killed him so long ago, she could still see his jeering <fex>smile</fex>.
She complimented me <fex>almost every morning</fex> on my smart starched shirts.
We were scolded <fex>in the kitchen</fex> by the biggest cook you've ever seen.
